text.p: Agricultural, energy and hardware group Wesfarmers Ltd said on Tuesday that growth in earnings in the current financial year would be at a slower pace than the 50 percent increase for 1996/97 ended June 30.
Most of the company's growth would come from existing businesses, managing director Michael Chaney told Reuters.
"We'll see reasonable growth this year," Chaney said.
Wesfarmers earlier reported a net profit of A$139.55 million, up from A$92.79 million a year earlier.
Chaney said the company would look outside of existing businesses for growth, such as opportunities in liquefied natural gas (LNG) in India.

However, he rated as "zero" the company's chances of resurrecting its bid for ICI Australia Ltd. The bid, however, had created a A$3.6 billion warchest, which could potentially be used for outside acquisitions, Chaney said.
Chaney said there were opportunities in a vastly undersupplied LNG market in India, although the highly regulated nature of the industry could prove discouraging.
Chaney also said the company's relatively low debt to equity ratio, currently in the low 20 percent range, left the company well-placed for growth.
Debt to equity should increase in the current year due to the company's earmarking of A$500 million for internal expansions, Chaney said.
This compared with expenditure of between A$100 million and A$300 million annually in previous years, he said.
"It's really spread across the curtain," Chaney said.
Business to get significant cash injections for growth included the Bunnings retail hardware division, seen as a star performer this year, coal and fertilisers and chemicals, Chaney said.
Chaney said so far that it has not been keen to look offshore for acquisitions to promote growth at Wesfarmers.
"What is being demonstrated is that so far it's not important in terms of achieving growth," Caney said.
"We're managing to achieve adequate growth through expanding our existing businesses."
By diversifying the company's assets, it is more likely Wesfarmers would continue to look mainly to grow its existing businesses, Chaney said.
"We've got a pretty good mix of businesses, whereas we used to be a lot narrower... It makes it more likely we'll expand than go into new areas," he said.
Wesfarmers shares ended 51 cents higher at A$12.60 on Tuesday.
